text: Never been on an international flight. If say we're flying in at noon on that day...would you plan something for later that day or evening? In Rome only the day we arrive and the next day. Just curious about how bad the jet lag will be. Don't want to waste any time.

comments.comment_text: I flew from Boston to Rome in 2015. We left Boston early evening, got to Rome in the morning with about an hour drive (with driver) to our hotel in Rome near the main termini. Too early to check in so we left our luggage at the hotel and walked around for a while, and got lunch. Checked into the hotel and rested for a while, then we had a bus/walking tour in the evening (end of March) with dinner included and saw the Trevi Fountain. Anyway, I slept through most of the bus tour, I couldn't keep my eyes open, lol. Maybe because I didn't sleep well on the plane. My friend was fine.

Jet Lag affects people differently, so there is no real norm. Changing time zones is generally a problem. Keep hydrated is a definite. Personally, I find flying with the sun (East > West), it doesn't affect me, but flying against the sun (West > East) unsettles me for sometimes up to 10 days. Biorhythms, I was told by a doctor.

They advise to do things until night time where you were at so you get on the right schedule. However, when we flew from Nebraska to Venice, we started out early in the day and then had to wait for a night flight in New York city. By the time we got to Venice, the only thing we could do was collapse in bed. We kept waking up and realized we needed to sleep more. So plan to do something, but don’t have reservations. It will depend on your body. ￼
If you’re getting in at noon, DO NOT nap/ keep yourself up, then head to bed a little early around 7 or so. Sleep in, you’ll be mostly caught up on sleep.

Domenic Policicchio III
Angelo Policicchio

Sonja Rasmussen if you can, stay up the entire night before you leave home. If you have to, take a 2-3 hour nap the evening before you fly out. You will hopefully sleep 4-5 hours on the plane. It almost 100% eliminates my jet lag
Plan something easy for arrival day. Stay awake until 9pm so your jet lag will start to dissipate.
Stay up all day - do not nap! Go to bed early
Yes, stay awake until normal bedtime.
Depends on where you start from!

I just did my Italy trip in late June/early July and I’m from Michigan. We landed at 10:30 Rome time. We had a 2:30 tour at the Vatican. We all wished we had NOT schedule a tour the first day. Take it easy, check in, walk around a bit, go to dinner, eat gelato. The rest of the trip was go, go, go. It would have been nice to have one day to recoup and just do whatever. We were EXHAUSTED from the travel and time changes.
Laina Hearney why are you laughing?
I usually land and proceed into the day as everyone else there is. Excitement should keep you going.
Flying from US… hit the ground running. You’ll sleep great the first night and enjoy your holiday!
I would plan a dinner at like 8 and get settled in snd take a nap
Jet lag gets worst when you’re back home, with a suitcase of dirty washing and a collection of bills, and red hot credit card
No jet lag....we hit the ground running!
Push through! Definitely check your bags, walk around to get the lay on the land, eat dinner and then to bed early. Get a good 8 hours sleep and wake up to enjoy an amazing Italian cup of coffee !

We live in the Seattle area. It’s a long flight day for us. We try to stay up until 7:00 in the evening. I would not book a tour, you will be too tired. We usually bring our luggage to our hotel, go have lunch at a outdoor cafe, walk around, check into our ￼hotel, and then have dinner. It’s so hard the first day!
Definitely plan on doing something immediately. Helps battle jet lag.

We travelled Australia to Istanbul
Took 24 hours
Arrived local time 5am
Youngest 9 yo
Dumped our bags and walked and explored for next 8 hours
Went to bed early local time
No jet lag
Adjust to their time straight up
Have a wonderful time!! Exciting!!

I take a walk, grab something to eat and then take a 90 minute nap after checking in. Then out and about, have dinner, do whatever and try to be asleep by midnight. I also take Unisom or some OTC sleep aid the first night to sleep through the night. I think that coming back to the US is much harder.

In addition to your flight origin, much depends on your age, health and ability to sleep sitting up 😉 Just make sure when you get there, no matter how bad you feel, to stay up until a reasonable bedtime at the new location. For us it's "the zombie walk" from lodging check-in until about 8 or 9 pm (but we are in our late 60's).
I land, check in and go explore. I try to keep moving until it’s bedtime where I’m visiting to lessen jet lag.
I live in Brazil, 10 hours flight, never had jet lag. It's all on your mind. Remember when you studied all night for an exam and had a party that night...
We left NJ at 7pm. Landed in Venice at 11am. Hit the ground running after we dropped the luggage off at the hotel. Went to bed at 11 pm.

I wouldn’t plan anything that requires purchasing tickets, as being on time will be entirely outside your control. That said, I’d definitely plan to drop off luggage and spend the day exploring. Rome is a pretty walkable city, and you’ll want to stay awake and active as long as possible to help your body adjust to the time change. Have fun!

We were doing a tour which started on Rome. We travelled 3 days earlier, booked an apartment and were jet lag free by the time the tour started. Unlike some of the travellers who suffered jet lag for the first 24 to 48 hours of the trip
I'd definitely get there earlier to adjust and rest up.

Refrain from sleeping in the hotel when you arrive. Just keep moving on your day of arrival and go to bed maybe 8 or 900pm..latest 10pm. Sightsee on your day of arrival but easy going. You don't want to waste your day since you don't have much time in Rome.

Just did Boston-FCO. 4:30pm flight. Arrived at FCO at 530am (11:30pm EST). So there was no sleep on the plane. I got a hotel room so we had a place to sit luggage until our train from Termini at 5pm

Had all good intentions to run around Rome that day but landing at 530am did not really cater to that.

We were luggage. Went to the hotel passed on and got to the train. I felt like I wasted the day but totally could not function.

For me it is best to stay awake and go to bed on their time,
We like to wander around and sometimes take the Hop on Hop off bus to get the lay of the land and Then have a nice dinner
If you plan a tour and your flight is delayed you will be out that money. I would look for free stuff to see or do or walk around.
Don’t nap the day you arrive, power through and it’ll make it easier to adjust
I definitely try to sleep in the plane as much as possible and then stay awake/do things until it’s time for bed that next night. Jet lag isn’t so bad that way.
Sleeping? There’s no sleeping in Italy.

The day of our arrival we booked a Viator Night Tour of Rome with Pizza & Gelato. The driver took us to all the main attractions which were lit up at night and we had pizza or pasta at Piazza Navona. It was the perfect activity for arrival day/night.

Do not watch a movie or read on the plane, take a good nap. Maybe take a Tylenol PM, it will really help. Where are you flying out of? Then, check in to your hotel and go out to see the sights ASAP. Pack good walking sneakers and synthetic socks. Try and get to bed by 11pm Rome time, and get up early. Do you have an itinerary for the 2nd day? Google now a good tour group for that day. Your hotel will hold your luggage all day.
Going is not bad as long as you rest on the plane. Coming back is rougher.
Sleep on plane. Full first day.

it really depends on your age...from where I fly we get in during early to late morning...becau
se you cant check in until 4 I usually have a driver pickup at airport and do a 4 hour tour...they will stop for coffee donut etc or quick lunch...by 4 im usually done...get to hotel...quick dinner and bed...wake up next morning at 8..but try not to do big things like Vatican until the third day..
Schedule it! Just make sure you leave enough time for any plane delays. We arrived it Italy at 1pm and scheduled a tour at 7pm. Enjoy every minute. You can sleep when you get home!

Don’t slow down when you arrive and go to bed at a normal hour like 9-10 pm. That doesn’t mean you should schedule a tour or something but definitely walk around, go to restaurants, get gelato, shop, etc.

Push through your jet lag, don’t think about what time it is at home.
Set your watch to local time. Walk around, go to dinner and go to bed at the same bed time in the local time zone.
You will adjust better.
If you can give in to your jet lag and sleep your day away.
By not planning anything on your 1st day does not mean you’ll be “wasting time” . The best part of italy is not having a plan. Every body is different, some jet-lag is days some a day or 2
Jet lag is bad but it’s worse to rest- get off the flight, check into your hotel and keep moving!
I wouldn’t book anything but plan to go out and explore with the aim of trying to stay up until round 9pm.

My advice is do not take a nap when you arrive. If you don't want to book a tour then just explore on your own, there's so much to see. Then go to sleep 9-10pm.
From the USA West Coast I usually sleep maybe 6hrs then I just adjust my body to the new time zone that same day.

I never plan something the day of arrival as you have no guarantee your plane will actually get there on schedule. I do bit of unpacking and get out and explore….see what’s in area where staying and depending on time explore further out in the city
Best thing to do is get out and walk and do a little sightseeing after landing. Then usually we are in bed pretty early like 9/10.

I need to crash FIRST after over night flight, I know it’s suggested not to do that, but to keep yourself up in order to get on local time. That does NOT work for me, crash, shower & go go go, now I feel good & ready, let’s do it!

We arrived in Rome from US at 8 am, our host allowed us to drop our bags early. We booked a golf cart tour ahead, knowing we would be wiped out but didn’t want to lose a day of touring. We loved the golf cart tour! Did not go to sleep till that evening. Fine the next day.

Transition by going to bed and getting up early for mane the week before if you can. The idea is to get your body on their tome zone. This will help you to sleep on the flight over and wake up somewhat rested when you arrive. I thought it was a crazy idea when I first did this for a trip to Italy but it worked. Pm if you have any questions. Enjoy your trip.
I always plan things for the arrival day. Nothing major though. For me what works the best for jetlag is to jump on the new schedule the same day

Depends on your age, how long you have been traveling including layovers, what the time difference is between your starting point and destination, how much sleep you got on the plane…….it is different for everyone.
Stay on their time when arriving
Where from, if it’s the UK, no problem.🙂
We got to Rome at 8:00 am and hit the ground running. I do t remember much about that day but my jet lag was minimal.
We planned a Viator night golf cart tour to see Rome on our first night. It was perfect!

We just flew into Rome last week… in the afternoon. We were going to take a bike tour at night, but decided to just walk around and go out to eat and get a decent nights sleep… and then got the early breakfast tour at the Vatican at 8am. We drove to Florence after that.
We flew into Rome around noon then took a train to Florence. We were too excited to do anything else but look around. Try to stay awake and go to sleep after dinner.

Everyone is different I don’t really suffer from jet lag but I do try and get myself into the time zone I arrive in as quickly as possible always get up the first morning at the time you would usually get up
We are. We want to take advantage of every minute
Courtney Greg
I always take hop on hop off bus to acclimated myself.
I never plan anything strenuous or with a reservation. But, do something to keep going and plan for an early dinner and early to bed.
Have to be mindful your plane may be late leaving. Our conecting flight in Dubai left two hours late and only just made train in Milan by one minute.
you've mot said how long your flight is, or what time you're landing... if I'm on a 2 hour flight then yeah I'm doing something that day, if it's a 12 hour flight I'm a bit more reticent...
I'm thinking jet lag will be pretty bad, so I scheduled golf cart tour and dinner day of arrival. I think I can manage that!
We had a 12 hour flight and didn’t experience any jet lag.

You manage jet lag while you are flying. Adjust your body during the flight to the time zone you arrive. Stay up all night to sleep on the plane and wake up at the normal morning time in the target time zone, for example.

Since you’re coming from Michigan, it sounds like your flight is overnight… if you don’t sleep comfortably on the plane, the jet lag can be tough the first day.

We usually don’t plan anything for arrival days in Europe—but stay up from landing until at least 8pm local time—because you’ll need to go to bed earlier than used to that first night, as the next day is likely when the jet lag hits you hard.
You can probably do some not so strenuous things. Even if it’s a bus tour around the city.
Only a meal. Nothing with time constraints though.
Stay up until local bed time then get up local morning time. Going from USA to Italy is easy to adjust. Coming back takes a few days.

Land, arrive at hotel, unpack, go get a coffee around the block, look at location around you. Pick a dinner site. Stay up. Have early dinner. Try to get to sleep at 9ish for the best results. Book tours for first full day.
check in, take a shower, and go explore as long as you can. That'll help with any jet lag.

Use an app that will tell you how to adjust your sleep schedule in advance of your trip to minimize jet lag. I find no words to describe the uncomfortablene
ss of unchecked jet lag.

We had a 16hr flight then 4 stoppover un Dubai then the final leg of 6hrs to Rome Frome Brisbane Australia. Landed about 11 rome time. No jet lag. Just went oit and toured for the arvo out for dinner then slept til.8am the next day

If you’re in the US, I feel like coming back home is always more difficult. Every time I travel to Europe I take a nap when I get there, then enjoy the rest of the day and go to bed around 10. It might be different for everybody but it works great for me.. now, coming back is a nightmare, it takes me days to recover.
SO hard to say. Its different for everybody. I’d say don’t book anything for first day. Just explore as long as your mind and body will allow on arrival day. Just don’t take a nap.
I would just get settled in, explore a little, eat early & go to bed early.
Thanks everyone! We are in Michigan US so it will be a long flight(s). But I think we'll try to stay up and around and maybe do a later Rome tour.

A general rule of thumb is to stay awake until a “normal” bedtime. Walk, and visit as much as you can, have a nice dinnner, then settle in for a good nights sleep. Try to wake up at a normal time and then go, go, go!
Don’t sleep!!! Enjoy every moment of life!! You can recuperate after !!!jet lag only hits you a few days later !!! Enjoy every moment there will be enough time to sleep after
Just some low-key things to keep yourselves awake! An espresso, gelato…a couple mile walk to get an initial impression of the city!

Never...ever make actual "hard" plans the day you land...anywere.
Just go to your lodging, relax and go explore freely. Way to much can go wrong on travel day.

Yes! Pack as much as you can in that first day so that you sleep well that night and try to get on the right time zone. The best thing you can do is eat, exercise and sleep on the time zone you're in, helps you acclimate quickly and reduce jet lag.
Fight through it and get on Italy time.
I just came back from a 6 day visit to friends and family in the UK from the Bahamas - as few naps as possible - sleep on the plane (if you can) and hit the ground running

Plan for something when u land. Hit the ground running and don’t eats any time . You will goto bed early that night-we just came back three weeks ago we were flying from America. We landed eight in the morning and we toured and walked around a Church that afternoon showered, then met our group for dinner and we’re to bed by 9 o’clock that night.
your jet lag will be much less if you get right into the time zone where you land - go and do! you will probably be tired but do NOT take a nap or you'll prolong your adjustment to the time.
I found I slept on the plane and the jet lag only hits me like 2 to 3 days later

As soon as you board, shift yourself into destination time.

The answer to your question depends a lot on where you’re coming from.

"Plan" is a relative term. I'd use that Day 1 to walk around Rome and just take it in. Drink coffee, get a gelato, try and stay awake and get on to local time as quickly as possible. I might not "plan" a formal tour or anything.

Hit the ground running fir as long as you can! Then go to bed at like 9pm Rome time! Sleep thru the night and up for breakfast and you’ll be good to go! Such and exciting amazing city you’ll do great!!

It depends
How awful tired you are, check in time, delays . You never know
Good thing everything is close, at lease a short walk and a nice dinner.
Good luck, relax and enjoy your trip 🙏
After 8 to 10 hours in a plane most people feel like shit. That said you you get out of the terminal it’s hard not to be excited. Listen to your body.

They say if you go to bed an hour earlier each night the week before your trip it helps your body prepare for the hour change. I plan to try to get my bedtime a couple hours earlier than normal but unsure I could do more than that.

Everyone reacts differently. Our first international trip, we went right to our apartment and took a nap, and getting up after a few hours was terrible. Since then, we always get right out. We have even driven multiple times for multiple hours, without issue. Not recommending that for everyone. We go to Italy a couple times a year from the US, and our typical arrival often includes Rome for the first day, and we have walked 10-15 miles after not sleeping on an overnight flight. It seems that helps re-set our body clock.

A week before, I adjust my sleep schedule 15-30 minutes to tge new time zone. The day of my flight. I set my watch to the new time zone. I never have problewith jet lag. I start earlier when going to Asia. Being doing this for 50 years
I would not book anything but walk around to see some of the sites from outside and then have dinner and go to sleep early just to try to adjust to the time zone.
Bc of possible travel delays, I’ve seen ppl recommend not booking any tours on the first day

From my experience, the overnight flights seem to arrive early in the AM after flying all night. If that's the case, it's best to store your bags in your hotel (until you can check in) and start walking around the city to start absorbing the sound and sights of the city.
I would only plan something like a hopon hopoff tour or a walk for first day. You don't know when you will arrive. I usually take a nap when I first get there and then go out for a walk .
We didn't book any tours that first day. Left it open and just explored on our own. Everyone handles jet lag differently, so best to leave it as a flexible day, in case you just want to go rest!

Where are you arriving from? It’s a huge difference between coming from long haul flights like Australia as opposed to a short distance like the UK for example. The day I arrive from anywhere I’m ready to collapse in a heap because I’ve travelled 25 hours on planes from Australia.

Keep awake, such as going for a walk and seeing the sights. Our plane into Rome was delayed several hours due to storms. Luckily we didn’t have anything booked otherwise we would have lost our money. (I travelled from Slovenia and there have been severe storms there.)
Arrived into Europe initially from Australia, door to door was 36 hours. We stayed awake by walking around Ljubljana and immediately went to their time zone, resisting the urge for a daytime nap. Was tired for a couple of days, but not too bad.

No matter where I fly to or how long I have been flying. I try to stay busy until bedtime the day I arrive. Yes it can suck and your tired. But I find it successful to not be jet lagged the rest of the trip.
We’ve just arrived in Sicily after flights and airport stopovers for nearly 30 hours. Get out and explore, go to bed at 9 and you will be fine. We had no jet lag.

Best advice is to stay awake and push through the day so you can start to get acclimated to the time change. I don’t know if I would plan a tour, but you can definitely site see and maybe do a hop on hop off bus. You will need at least an hour for customs and then plan an hour (should be less) to your hotel and then time to check in and get acclimated, that’s all assuming no delays.

My son and I were just there from Ottawa. No jet lag at all (slept as much as we could on the plane). We were able to easily stay up until 11pm and then were up and running at 8am the next day. Coming back has been another story
Noon is perfect! Get a Hop-on Hop-off bus tour and see the city a bit. Then enjoy a fantastic meal and hit the hay early!
Keep moving! We even make our kids sleep on the plane and get up and power through until at least 9 or so. You definitely don’t want to wast a day sleeping or mess up your new sleep schedule!

I travel overseas from Canada regularly and I think it best to hit the ground running.Try and sleep 2-3 hours on the plane. If you can check in early, I feel like taking a shower makes a huge difference and then head out right away. If you're coming from Michigan, you probably land relatively early on in the day, so I'd say book something for the afternoon, whether a hop on hop off, or something else not too demanding, maybe a visit to the Borghese galeries or book an entry ticket to the Pantheon and walk through Piazza Navona. Save the Vatican for the second day as it requires quite a bit of time. You can also just walk around to see the outside of the Coliseum, go to Trevi Fountain, etc. That being said, that works for me but I find that for my travel companions, it really depends on the person. Some need a long nap, some are a write-off except for dinner and minimal walking around.
You’ll be too excited and will power through it
It all depends where u are flying from? Is it a short 9 hour flight or a long 29 hour flight?
After reading g from so so many here and other sites I wouldn’t book a tour. I’d walk and explore. If you book a tour and flight is cancelled or delayed you lose that money.

Sleep as much as you can on the plane. We hit the ground running at 10:00 am and didn’t get to our hotel until around 10:00 pm. We adjusted to the time change right away. (This was our TA suggestion and it worked.)

I usually land in Milan at around 6am from Melbourne (with one brief stop in Singapore that totals around 23 hours) after not having slept much on the plane, unfortunately. I then stay awake all day until at least after dinner - it helps I love coffee, I suppose. Of course I feel some tiredness but I found it's the best way to get rid of the jet lag ASAP. Forget what the time is at home, make the most of your day in Rome and don't dwell on it. And don't give in to napping during the day in the first few days, that is a no no for me!

Drop your bags at your hotel and hit the streets. With an arrival of noon, I would not pay for any tour in case you flight is delayed and you miss it. If you arrive early morning, that’s different. I make a dinner reservation but that’s it. Unfortunately the first night, I can’t fall asleep until late so I usually stay out later to tire myself out and eat later. I’m traveling from NY. Everyone is different though!

text: Hi looking into planning a visit to Venice in the month of November. I have been reading about the high tides and flooding. Is it better to fly into Florence and just do a day trip to Venice at that time of year? Thank you 😊

Personally, fly into Venice for 2 nites, partly to get a day to acclimate and wade around Venice then train to Florence for 4/5 days do a guided tour of Tuscany plus explore the amazing Florence.

text:

Would it be worth getting on the train staying in Naples but heading down the amafli coast for the day Saturday?

not worth it

No! You'll be exhausted and vulnerable to being pick pocketed! Take a short nap and enjoy rome. Hopefully your flight won't be delayed. You shouldn't plan anything big for first day since that may hapoen
LORD NO 🤣🤣🤣. Get settled, keep moving, go to bed early like 8pm & hit the decks running next day on Italian time

Update on Rome so far:

- Pickpockets: havent had any problems. Just like others on this page have said, just keep an eye on your stuff like you normally would in a big city, and you’ll be okay. Even in alleys where theres less tourists, I have yet to see a single local look sketchy and try something with me (traveling on my own). - Crowds: honestly not as bad as this page made it out to be. Not sure if its just less tourists in general right now, but its definitely manageable. Didnt feel like cattle/so tightly packed in like I thought I would be lol. Even at the Trevi Fountain, it seems like a regular crowd for a tourist attraction in the states.

- Temps: not too bad either!! The forecast does say it’ll be in the 90s later this week so I may change how I feel then lol but so far its been mid 80s and feels fine. A nice breeze in the morning, but then is full sunny hot weather from 11am to sunset. Veryy similar to Chicago summers. Walk near shade, use sunscreen, bring a fan, DRINK WATER.

will update if anything changes, but its been a great trip so far 🙂

I am back home from a whirlwind, amazing trip to Italy…my first but certainly not my last!!! A quick recap below:

Florence, Day 1.

Landed in Rome.
Beautiful car drove us to train.
Made it to Florence.
Promptly went exploring…the streets, the people, the vibe is like nothing we have ever experienced. Beautiful and passionate and hot and stunning mixed together with delicious gelato and a cafe for Prosecco.

Ended with dinner at Osteria Pastella -
Blown away.

First full day in Italy did not disappoint.

Next up, a 10 hour tour.

First stop, Pisa.

Next stop, San Gimignano. Gelato and exploring.

Next stop, Tuscany. Lunch and wine tasting at the Palagetto winery - owned by a 29 year old woman.

Next stop, a castle in Monteriggoni. Very cool. Built during the war between Florence and Sienna which lasted 300 years.

Last stop, Sienna. A beautiful city with all red bricks (hence the name).

Ended the day with the most delicious pizza.

Next, day of art.
First stop, a guided tour of the Accademia Gallery. The art was so beautiful it left me breathless. The statue of David is a sight to see. 15 feet tall and a true work of God.

Next, a 2 hour walking tour all through Florence.

Next, a guided tour at the Uffizi museum. Ended up being private as the other group never showed. You can spend days exploring every room in that museum. My favorite was da Vinci and Michelangelo.

Next stop, a wonderful leather store. The owner was so kind. I bought a beautiful leather jacket and bag.

Next stop, gelato.

Ended the night with dinner at Trattoria Zaza. Delicious.

20,000+ steps later, we are exhausted and happy.

Day number 4 landed us in Rome!

After a dicey start (we got off at the wrong train station in Rome and got a bit turned around), we made our way to the hotel.

Checked in and began a 2.5 hour walk around Rome. Trevi Fountain was beautiful, a quick lunch, gelato and more exploring.

Made our way to the Argo Di Costantino for a tour of the Palatine Hill, Roman Forum and Colosseum. Breathtaking, all of it.

Sweaty and exhausted but quick showers and dinner in Trastevere - a delicious restaurant called Tonnarello. Gelato again.

Finally, rooftop for sunset.

Day two in Rome did not disappoint!!

Breakfast at the hotel (cappuccino & croissant!)

Began our journey walking and ended up at the Spanish Steps.

From there, stumbled upon the Pantheon and ended up grabbing a light lunch at a cafe looking straight at it - what a sight!

From there we made our way to the Vatican. On a tour, we were guided through the Vatican Museum, Sistine Chapel & St. Peter’s Basilica. It was quite powerful.

Ended the night in the Jewish Ghetto - a really beautiful part of the city. Dinner at Giggetto al portico d'Ottavia - Josh’s favorite meal so far.

Ended our time in Rome.

Car to train station.
Train to Naples.
Car to Positano (winding & on a cliff)

…and made it to this magical place that exists in fairytales.

Lunch at our beautiful hotel, relaxing and watching a movie and dinner at Chez Black (a 20 minute walk down a massive hill - and back up after, slowly, while stopping for gelato).

A full day in Positano.

Started the day off with a sunrise photoshoot - the sweetest photographer from @flytographer. https://l.instagram.com/?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pierpaoloperri.com%2F&e=AT2kJSbJ2MBt6itMq0ZsDAvIfbjQhQNE2mCjvNNCk7vH24ogPI2jhcCxnt-jQJfo5CEdo3Q-C9GYIxgwPa29BXZodi53eK2gRhzX

Spent all day at La Scolgliera Beach Club (there is a very small public beach, otherwise you rent chairs, which include water, an umbrella and super comfy seats).

Dinner at D’Aiello Ristorante.

Positano. I 🩷 you.

Beach Club at a secret hidden beach we found through a cave.

Dinner at Il Capitano - a glass balcony overlooking the most beautiful view.

Last day, traveling back to Rome - ended with shopping and dinner at Enzo, YUM!!!

Overall, best trip!!!! Cannot wait to go back!!!!
